comments:
I am not sure if this is a problem with the Eclipse IDE or the Eclipse Ant
Integration I have logged the problem under Ant.

We use Ant from within the Eclipse JVM (i.e. no seperate jvm is launched)

Our build process failed. This left a corrupt jar file.

Attempting to delete it via IDE (under the folder where it sits) results in an
error ( please find EclipseDeleteError1.png attached )

We are unable to delete it from the file system via Win XP Explorer - it says
jar is used by some other program.

Log file provides this:

I decided to exit the IDE: which resulted in an error (see
EclipseDeleteError2.png). Not sure why this happened and how this is related to
the previous problem.

Managed to delete the file from WinXP Explorer (phew ... as you guys know this
can be a problem sometimes and one has to reboot or kill explorer shell)

cheers and good will

From the description it would appear that the build did not properly close all access to the JAR file. 
There really is not much we can do here as indicated from the error that you get when attempting to delete from WinXP.

Planning to close but I am open to suggestions?

As you know Ant being such a high level script there is not way you can "trap" the build error and close the "file handles".

We get similar errors when we run ant from command prompt shell. But the jar files are not locked.

Is the Ant Integration or the fact that "Ant is run from the same JVM" causes these locks ?

Can the Ant Integration release all such locks ?

Groping in the dark here.
Cheers

Ant from the commandline runs and then exists...the file handles are released when the VM exists.

When you run in the same JRE, the VM does not exist until you exit Eclipse and therefore some of the locks incorrectly remain.

I am not sure how we would know which locks to release and which to leave alone?

I understand. We are running in external JVM at the moment. No problem.
This also means the "run in same JVM" option is very fragile.

This is really a problem with Ant isn't it ?

Maybe we should close this bug and wait for Ant to get better ?

"run in same JVM" option is very powerful and with power comes the ability to cause problems :-)

If you can reproduceably make the Ant build fail and track where it is improperly closing a stream etc, it would help them get better by logging a bug report.

Marking as WONTFIX as we cannot fix this problem.
